Learning English through Sports Communication
Because of the lack of sports facilities, some people in your community have suggested that schools should allow the public to use their sports facilities after school hours.
Write a letter to the editor of the Hong Kong Daily stating your opinion. Support your opinion with three reasons.

Dear Editor,

Despite the government’s endeavor to increase the number of sports venues, many enthusiastic sports-doers and even professional athletes are still plagued with the lack of sports facilities. Worse still, with an ineffective booking system to identify real end-users, unscrupulous ticket scalpers make the booking of sports facilities even harder. In this regard, I am writing to call on schools to open their door to the residents of their neighborhood who eager to do sports after school hours before the commissioning of more new sports premises and development of a more intelligent booking system.

In view of the low usage rate of sports facilities in schools after school hours, allowing the public the access to the facilities will have limited impacts on students, and better utilize the resources. Normally, all students’ activities such as P.E. lessons, assemblies and sports team practices will end or halt after 6 p.m, and the concerned facilities will be left idle afterwards. Having regard to the student’s schedule and daily routine of working class who usually does sports after work, schools could choose to open their facilities to members of the public after 6. p.m to minimise the nuisance caused by sports-doers while still benefitting society as a whole. Given that schools usually consist of several basketball courts and open spaces, the open-to-public policy after school hours will certainly go a long way towards the problem of the lack of sports facilities.

In addition, the open-to-public policy could be beneficial to both schools and society economically. School managements and parents opposing the policy are of the view that schools open to the public will pose potential threats to students. In respect of the security concern, the authority should hire more security staff in addition to janitors to monitor the use of the facilities and maintain the order at the scene. This would generate hundreds of job opportunities to the benefit of the low-skilled labour and the underprivileged. Schools can also charge users a certain amount of admission fees with a view to maintaining the quality of sports facilities and paying overhead costs. The surplus generated, if any, can be used at the discretion of the schools in enhancing teaching quality and welfare of students. This will be a win-win situation for both schools and society.

Allowing the public to use the schools’ sports facilities will also facilitate public engagement in sports and help nurture more elite athletes for Hong Kong. The city’s sporting culture is improving. The Standard Chartered Marathon had barely 1,000 participants for its first race, but now it is one of the largest mega sports events around the world. By allowing easier access to sports facilities, the open-to-public policy will be another boost to the public’ attitude towards sports, thereby increasing community participation in sports. Furthermore, with more sports venues provided, athletes can enjoy much more practicing time, and hopefully maintain their competitiveness compared to their international counterparts with a view to achieving better results.

While this may not be the ultimate solution to address the problem of lacking sports facilities, the open-to-public policy may serve as a quick fix for the pressing needs. The government should explore the feasibility of the policy and collaborate with suitable schools on a trial basis as soon as possible. The priority should accord to schools with a variety of sport facilities. In the meantime, the authority should also step up its efforts in searching lands for sports and recreation facilities, and expedite its review on the booking system for sports facilities.

Yours faithfully,
Chris Wong
